text: hi everyone i haven't drunk any water
yet today here the internet's busiest
music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
claro project
sling this is a brand new album from
singer and
songwriter miss claire cottrell aka
claro
whose first album as claro as well as
some of her early singles that popped
off on the internet
put her at the top of the bedroom pop
food chain now
2019's immunity didn't exactly do it for
me as the record in my opinion was a
little all over the place
but the lp did showcase a lot of
potential but i had no idea that
clara would be capitalizing on that
potential with none other than
jack antonoff on production here with a
totally new sound
the lo-fi beats and somewhat rough and
driven guitars of her last lp
are totally gone on this record as sling
sounds a lot more like a combination
of the depressive songwriting and
low-key vocal layering of elliot smith
fed through a series of soft rock and
singer-songwriter-type instrumentals
dabbling in jazz
folk and charming piano tunes think of
like fleetwood mac
combined with joni mitchell for a
generation of
post-grizzly bear indie fans living
in an objectively darker world and it's
an lp overall that doesn't really jump
out at you
it's an experience that stuns with its
quiet subtleties its quiet melancholy
not to mention the production on this
thing is fantastically ornate for how
quiet and soft it is and continuously
gentle even in its most
decisive moments like the groovy dance
beat on the supremely catchy amoeba
now there are spots on this lp where i
wish the songwriting or the
instrumentation went a bit
harder or that claire had some stronger
vocal performances to bring to the table
but most of the tracks here are so sweet
and entrancing and pretty
it's only so often i'm left wanting more
on the opening track bambi we hear
claire singing curious poetry about
being at the mercy of a situation
and of a universe out of her control
and just considering leaving to save
herself a headache
this is set to really steady piano
chords as well as horns
reed and bass that sounds like it's
straight out of the 70s it's so warm in
its sound but also so cold in its
heartache such a good opener i love how
we have a thematic change as well as a
musical change on the bridge too
it's just smart songwriting the ride
from here to the finish on this lp
is pretty smooth but varied enough to
stay engaging
there's the groovy amoeba that i
mentioned earlier meanwhile the track
partridge finds
strength in sonic tenderness there's
something about claire's whisper quiet
vocal harmonies on this track that's
kind of haunting
and even though vocally claire is not
going above and beyond on this track
i love that jack does his best to
complement her singing style with these
drums and bass that are just
tiptoeing across the mix along with
chilly electric piano keys and just
very very very quietly weeping lead
guitars xenius is a pretty interesting
moment on the lp as it suddenly busts
into this groove that sounds like an
indie focified version of a hard rock
song that's a
set to a desert road trip my only issues
are i think it could have hit that point
sooner and the
kind of slinky guitar or steel
solo toward the end is a really sour and
doesn't exactly
complement the sound of the track all
that much
blouse was a teaser to the lp and is a
pretty but also
pretty boilerplate indie folk tune
admittedly it's unadventurous but i
still do like the lyrics on the track
quite a bit
as claro explores these feelings of
being objectified and stared at in a
sexualized way and
these feelings of being fed up and
defeated as a result of this like really
come off the track
strong the first leg of the track wade
is pure piano backed elia smith worship
that suddenly shifts into some
instrumental passages that are wondrous
are pretty especially as we hit these
layers of horns and
flutes it's actually kind of heavenly
but these changes arrive
at an almost random pace and don't flow
all that coherently
harbor by comparison is a much more
sensibly structured track about
uh some incredible heartache unrequited
love and isolation
we kind of see claire in another moment
where she has to like
break something or cut something off in
order to self-preserve
and meanwhile that narrative is being
fit against instrumentation that's fit
for
a dance scene out of a disney princess
movie it's incredibly
bittersweet in that way slang coasts
into a fairly decent last leg
the song joni is an unexpected but sweet
instrumental track on the lp that i
think
enhances the enchantment factor of it
then the song reaper takes things in a
folky direction once again
and i am one more time
more interested in claire's poetry than
i am the instrumental itself
which i guess isn't too much of a dick
considering that i'll spare you
pain i can feel my shame creep through
that floor i can't [ __ ] it up if it's
not there at
all is one of the most devastating lines
on the entire project i wish little
changes had a stronger finish
as a song it's one of those tracks that
feels a little scant
writing wise and structure wise in the
tracklist to me and then the finisher
is one of those points that i was
referencing earlier in the review where
i
really really really wish the vocal
performance was stronger because as
lovely as this
bed of baroque pop instrumentation is
claire does get a little too buried in
it
still with that being said though i
think this lp is uh
instrumentally uh songwriting wise and
maturity wise
a pretty big growth and improvement past
immunity
there is still room to progress
on the vocal side of this record and
some of the songs on here certainly
needed just a little bit more time to
incubate
even if they did end up being very
ordinary and
beautifully arranged but yes again this
record to me for claro feels like growth
that feels like
advancement it feels like more
creativity
more skill she is better embodying and
channeling her
influences and mixing them all together
in a way that
doesn't seem quite as derivative as her
work in the past and of course on the
production side jack antonov totally
kills it
i'm feeling a light to decent seven on
this one
tran position have you given this record
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best
what should i review next hit the like
if you like please subscribe and please
don't cry
hit the bell as well over here next to
my head it's another video you can check
out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel claro
sling album review music
forever
